docs.lead_paragraph: Really, how hard could it be? Walk into a crowded subway car, bend down and ask a seated stranger -- politely but directly -- to give up his or her seat. O.K., sweeten the pot. Stir in noise, heat and humidity. Add elbows, backpacks and baby strollers. Unleash the Republican convention and its related aboveground protests. Toss in the supreme commuter irritant -- the evening rush. Shake well.

headline.main: 'Excuse Me. May I Have Your Seat?'; Seeking a Favor, and Finding It, Among the Strangers on a Train

docs.abstract: Anthony Ramirez and Jennifer Medina article describes their re-enactment of Dr Stanley Milgram's 1972 experiment to see if New Yorkers would give up their subway seats if asked; say they experienced same anxiety as Milram's students 30 years ago; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Really, how hard could it be? Walk into a crowded subway car, bend down and ask a seated stranger - politely but directly - to give up his or her seat.

byline.original: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ and JENNIFER MEDINA

docs.lead_paragraph: The children of the victims of Sept. 11 deal with the burden of mourning a private loss that is historic in stature.

headline.main: Growing Up Grieving, With Constant Reminders of 9/11
headline.print_headline: Growing Up Grieving, With Constant Reminders of 9/11

docs.snippet: The children of the victims of Sept. 11 deal with the burden of mourning a private loss that is historic in stature.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ask anyone at City Hall: bringing the Olympics to New York City is not an easy job. A group of ambitious businessmen and social activists have discovered that the same thing applies not only to the kind of Olympics that feature pole vaulting and parallel bars but also to a much different kind that would match the cultural skills of contestants from around the world. In early 2000 three Korean men -- Seok Hyun Hong, a wealthy Seoul newspaper publisher; Jang Hong Koh, a holistic martial arts grand master and businessman; and the Rev. Kiyul Chung, a United Methodist minister and longtime grass-roots organizer for Korean reunification -- envisioned an Olympics of traditional arts as a way to promote peace and to draw the world's cultures together, in much the same way that the Olympic Games strive to do.The first problem, however, was settling on a name for the competition.

headline.main: An Olympic Track for Cultural Hurdlers

docs.abstract: Article on efforts by Seoul newspaper publisher Seok Hyun Hong, holistic martial arts grand master and businessman Jang Hong Koh and United Methodist minister Rev Kiyul Chung to develop international competition in traditional arts as way to promote peace and draw world's cultures together; result, first World Culture Open, will take place on September 9 at Lincoln Center's Avery Fisher Hall and present its first three prizes of $100,000 each to groups that show achievements in arts, humanitarian service and holistic healing; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A group of ambitious businessmen has created an international contest to reward groups that have demonstrated achievements in arts and humanitarian service.
